utterances: Thank you Julie.
You're welcome Robert.
That's NPR health policy correspondent Julie Rovner.
And you can add this to the list of problems in Baghdad.
It's getting riskier and harder to find bread.
There's been a string of attacks on bakeries across the capitol, mainly by insurgents trying to further destabilize daily life.
Here's NPR's Jamie Tarabay.
Iraq's traditional bread is diamond shape, puffy and doughy inside.
Cream cheese and overripe tomatoes is a typical Iraqi sandwich.
Serve a kebob in there, or mop up a plate of rice and lamb with bits of it.
Low carbs doesn't work.
Here, it's as much a part of daily life as water, and the insurgents know this.
(Soundbite of men speaking foreign language)
Business at this bakery in the neighborhood of Kerada(ph) is brisk.
One man slips flower into the dough and kneeds.
Another shoves discs of dough into the oven with a long, wooden board.
Beside him, a worker stacks freshly baked bread into piles, puts them in plastic bags, and ties them with twist tops.

As he punches keys on the cash register, Saad Abu Ahmed(ph) says his customers depend on his bread now more than they used to, because of frequent cuts in electricity and the hikes in the cost of cooking oil and gas.
(Through Translator) If there is no bread, there will be chaos.
Look at the prices of gas (unintelligible).
People can't bake bread at home.
So all the burden is on our bakeries.
So what would happen shuts down?
We pray to God for love and security.
Abu Ahmed may pray for security, but also keeps a couple of automatic rifles on hand should anyone attack his store.
He says the attacks on other bakeries have frightened some of his workers away, and instead of saying open late, as he used to, he shuts his doors at 7:00 p.m.
Bakery worker Ali Mahasan(ph) says his wages are good, but he doesn't know how much longer he can do his job.
(Through translator) If you want the truth, there is no security anywhere.
(Unintelligible) a couple of days ago, they killed workers in a bakery shop.
I saw it on TV.
Iraqis can read about it, too.
A local newspaper ran the front page picture of a woman shopping at a bakery where an AK-47 was shown hanging over stacks of bread.
The reports of attacks are frequent.
Last week, at least three more bakery workers were killed in the neighborhood of Dohra(ph), when gunmen stormed in and opened fire in their shop.
Ali Mahasan says the bakeries are being attacked because the workers are mostly Shiite.
(Through translator) First of all, because they are Shiite, and second because they support Muqtada al-Sadr.
But I can't tell you any more.
Most of the men who work in bakeries here in Baghdad are Shiite and poor.
Most come from Shiite areas in the south, where wages are low and jobs are few.
They usually come and work in Baghdad for around 20 days, go home to their families for 10 days, then come back.
Brahd Shalouf Hussein(ph) comes from the mainly Shiite province of Mesan, near the border with Iran.
He stays with relatives when he works in Baghdad.
Despite the dangers, he wants to keep his job here.
(Through translator) There are many people in Mesan who are unemployed who wish to come work here, but because of the explosions, they're afraid to.
They think working for 2,000 or 3,000 Dinar is better than coming here.
They're close to their families.
It's only about security.

Insurgents have routinely hit at civilians since the beginning, attacking open marketplaces, Friday mosque prayers, and unemployment lines, with the aim of undermining any chance to rebuild after the U.S.-led invasion.
The breadline has always been a place where an attack strikes at the heart of the ordinary person.
Everyone has to eat.
Unemployed Huidu Halhad(ph) buys bread every day as he can, but not at the same place each time.
(Through translator) I don't know which bakery I should go to, because I don't know which one of them might be targeted.
You can see how bad things are.
If I stand in the street and a car parks close by, I leave straight away, in case it explodes.
Because of the attacks, many bakeries have closed down, forcing people to travel to safer areas of Baghdad to buy bread.
Some, like Huidu Halhad, try to avoid certain areas if they think they're prone to attack.
Some steer clear of bakeries near police stations, or ones popular with Iraqi police, who are also frequently targeted.
(Through translator) If there are many people standing in line, I won't buy.
You never know what might happen, and I'm afraid.
I get afraid.
Why shouldn't I?
Someone might blow himself up in the middle of us all.
Last night, a car bomb blew up outside a Shiite mosque across the street from a bakery.
Eleven people were killed.
Jamie Tarabay, NPR News, Baghdad.
People in hotels or trailers may feel lucky compared to those on the Gulf Coast who are still living in shelters.
NPR's Kathy Lohr visited the shelter in D'Iberville, Mississippi.
A round wooden table underneath a white tent at the D'Iberville Civic Center is a gathering place for those who live inside the building that has become a shelter.
Katrina devastated the town, just east of Biloxi.
The people living here are trying to get a handle on why they're waiting so long for help.
Mr.
FORREST JORDAN(ph) (Hurricane Survivor): Now I had the guy from FEMA tell me that they are over budget and that they cannot provide that financial assistance anymore, and that's what's getting to me.
That's Forrest Jordan.
He's been moved from shelter to shelter, from a high school gymnasium to one of the cruise ships.
He's now called this civic center home for the past three weeks.
Jordan chose to come to this shelter because he thought he'd have a better chance of getting his life back together here.
They got jobs, at least that's what I heard.
I thought I'd come here and start making $100 a day.
I found out that's a myth.
But I figured I'd come back to D'Iberville, because I'd lived here for five months, and try to start my life over here, and it's still a struggle.
I'm still trying to find something to get my life started over again.
And I now lost--when you lose everything in a storm and you don't have anything, literally only the clothes that are on your back, and thankfully the bed that was donated to me, what can you do?
Jordan was working at Wendy's when Katrina hit, but he says he couldn't get back to work because so much of the Gulf Coast was in ruins.
He's single and he admits it's been rough, but it may be the hardest on families who are still without homes.
Papa's going to have to get you a spoon later.
Wait.
Wait a minute.
Tell Mama.
Say, `We got a spoon, Mama?'
...(Unintelligible).
That's a fork.
Gina!
Give me two spoons.
Joey Waits calls to his wife, Gina, across the room.
It's dinnertime, and their two youngest children, Gabrielle, who's three years old, and Dylan, just two, are excited about dessert.
It's pink Jell-O.
The kids are quiet now, but sometimes they can be pretty noisy, and Gina says that's caused some hard feelings.
Most of them's copping attitudes, but I just tell them like it is.
I ain't worried about them, about them crying all the time.
Dylan!
Ah!
There's not much for the children to do.
The floor is covered with cots set up just a few feet apart from each other.
Gina and Joey Waits occupy a back corner with the two small children and their 12-year-old daughter, Sabrina.
There's a small room set up at the back where the kids can play.
Sabrina Waits watches her younger brother and sister in the evenings.
She helps pass the time by talking to a couple of Red Cross volunteers about one of her favorite concerts.
This one guy who was in the group, I told him he was hot and he shook my hand and called me `sweetheart.'
Unidentified Woman #1: Aww!
Just because I told him he was hot.
Unidentified Woman #2: ...(Unintelligible).
Then I got his autograph.
Just for fun, Sabrina Waits decides to sing along to a CD, something she loves to do.
(Soundbite of music)
(Singing) There's a cold feelin', runnin' up and down my spine.
FEMA has offered the Waits family space on a cruise ship, but Gina says that's out of the question because she has such small children.
So Gina, her husband, Joey, who's disabled with a heart problem, the kids and their grandmother continue to wait for a trailer to be set up on their own property.
It's less than a mile from the shelter site.
(Soundbite of machinery)
Near the corner of Quave Road and Beach Bayou, a bulldozer lifts bricks, chunks of Sheetrock and even a child's red bicycle from the debris.
A house is being torn down across the street from where Gina Waits lived.
Her land and most of the area all around it is bare except for the foundations.
